results.title: Bell and Howell Zoomatic Director Series Model 414 PD
results.brief_description: The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F. Kennedy on camera in 1963.

constellations_primary.name: Papa-paparazzi
constellations_primary.description: Media attention and paparazzi from the assassination of JFK to Lady Gaga's music video.

results.title_for_label: Bell and Howell Zoomatic Director Series Model 414 PD
results.description: Cameras can be used to record history, but they can also become part of it as well. The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F Kennedy on camera in 1963. The footage was sold to LIFE magazine, who printed it frame-by-frame, and became a key part of the FBI investigation. The increasing popularity of home movies led to the development of more affordable technology that was common in households just like the Bell and Howell Model.
description_for_label: Cameras can be used to record history, but they can also become part of it as well. The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F Kennedy on camera in 1963. The footage was sold to LIFE magazine, who printed it frame-by-frame, and became a key part of the FBI investigation. The increasing popularity of home movies led to the development of more affordable technology that was common in households just like the Bell and Howell Model.

results.title: Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR
results.brief_description: The Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR was a durable, 16mm camera used by combat photographers like Robert Capa during the Spanish Civil War and Australian Neil Davis in the Vietnam War.

constellations_primary.name: Conflict to cartoons
constellations_primary.description: The Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR was a durable, 16mm camera frequently used by combat photographers like Robert Capa during the Spanish Civil War and Australian Neil Davis in the Vietnam War, but this Constellation goes to some much brighter places.

results.description: The Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR was a durable, 16mm camera used by combat photographers like Robert Capa during the Spanish Civil War and Australian Neil Davis in the Vietnam War. Davis in particular, preferred this model due to its lightweight and dependable nature, namely in challenging environmental conditions like shooting on the frontline with South Vietnamese troops. Travelling light enabled Davis to become part of the action and blend seamlessly to show the world the harsh realities of what was actually happening on the ground in Vietnam. Combat photographers often carried several cameras, including a bulkier model with a separate sound recorder.
description_for_label: The Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR was a durable, 16mm camera used by combat photographers like Robert Capa during the Spanish Civil War and Australian Neil Davis in the Vietnam War. Davis in particular, preferred this model due to its lightweight and dependable nature, namely in challenging environmental conditions like shooting on the frontline with South Vietnamese troops. Travelling light enabled Davis to become part of the action and blend seamlessly to show the world the harsh realities of what was actually happening on the ground in Vietnam. Combat photographers often carried several cameras, including a bulkier model with a separate sound recorder.

results.title: Pop-Up Television Radio Model TR-475U
results.material_description: plastic body with silver metal handle, trim and antenna.
results.brief_description:
National Transistor TV. Model TR-475U. Pop-up screen and pull out handle for portablity.
No power cords, batteries only.

Brand: National

Serial no. F 3 (??) 1113
TQF8125

National Transistor TV
Model TR-475U DC12V 11W
Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd
Made in Japan
TBM 81685

Caution: To prevernt electric shock, do not remove cover. No user-serviceable parts inside, and pilot lamp soldered in place. Refer servicing to qualified service personnel.

Note: Before opening the pop-up portion of this TV. Please release two red screws fixed on the bottom side of the set. These screws are fixed for delivery safety only. The battery enclosed in this TV receiver is disconnected to assure longer life.

Before use, it must be properly connected. Please see instruction manual. For longer battery life: charge more than 10 hours before initial use. After each use once a month.

There are no power cords accompanying the TV.
results.description:
The National Transistor TV Radio Model TR-475U is a battery-operated, portable model features an inbuilt radio and a ‘pop-up’ television screen.
National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: National Ranger 505 Transistor TV
results.creator_credit: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.description:
National Ranger 505 Transistor TV is a portable TV with handle, small screen and folding antennae. The television was completely portable - it could be powered with either mains power or batteries, allowing the user to kick back and take the TV to the beach, campground or backyard.

National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: Videosphere 'Space Helmet' CRT Television Set
results.brief_description:
Videosphere was a JVC CRT television that was shaped in the form of a space helmet. It was first introduced in 1970 and was sold up until the early-1980s. It was popular for its modern design; the alarm clock base was an option however most units have a plain base.

Videospheres were produced in large quantities in white, red, black and orange in the seventies with a grey colored model also released in the 1980s. The design of the videosphere is said to have been inspired by the film 2001: A Space Odyssey,[1] though the videosphere’s shape in itself remains as one of the most iconic examples of the early 1970s design ethos.

The sci-fi look of the TV saw a red model appear as a background prop in the 1999 film The Matrix, though they have appeared in sci-fi films since the early 70s. Soylent Green had a red model on screen as a prop.The 1972 film Conquest of the Planet of the Apes, a black videosphere was shown with a color capable tube and a slot that allowed a cassette tape capable of playing video. Humorously, the color image on the videosphere goes from being rectangular in one scene to round in another scene.

JVC Videosphere / Made in Japan / (Yokohama) / Serial # 10600147
240 V / 50Hz / 12V / 11W (Australian AC power plug). Has plastic casing, control dials positioned at the back of object with an aerial and chain to hang unit.

results.title: US Navy Ciné-Kodak Special
results.brief_description: Eastman Kodak introduced the Ciné-Kodak Special in 1933. The silent 16mm camera was durable and lightweight enough to be used by combat photographers working in the field and Kodak manufactured a military version in all-black without the usual chrome edges.

constellations_primary.name: Australia and WW2
constellations_primary.description: A constellation exploring representations of Australians during World War 2.

results.description: Footage captured during war has the ability to give audiences a sense of what is happening in combat, documenting the frontlines with an unflinching lens and bearing witness to atrocities. Yet it can also be used as propaganda to enlist forces, making it a powerful tool. Eastman Kodak introduced the Ciné-Kodak Special in 1933 following on from its earlier model the Ciné-Kodak in 1923. The silent 16mm camera was durable and lightweight enough to be used by combat photographers working in the field and Kodak manufactured a military version in all-black without the usual chrome edges.
description_for_label: Footage captured during war has the ability to give audiences a sense of what is happening in combat, documenting the frontlines with an unflinching lens and bearing witness to atrocities. Yet it can also be used as propaganda to enlist forces, making it a powerful tool. Eastman Kodak introduced the Ciné-Kodak Special in 1933 following on from its earlier model the Ciné-Kodak in 1923. The silent 16mm camera was durable and lightweight enough to be used by combat photographers working in the field and Kodak manufactured a military version in all-black without the usual chrome edges.
